title: 115_hr2966
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States-Cuba Normalization Act of 2017". Congress finds that Cuba is no longer a threat to the United States or the Western Hemisphere, the trade embargo declared in 1962 is not effective, and extending normal trade relations to Cuba would help its economy grow based on free market principles. The United States can support democratic change and human rights in Cuba by promoting trade, travel, communications, and cultural exchanges. Expanding bilateral trade relations can further progress in Cuba on human rights and democratic rule. Cuba's membership in international trade organizations warrants unconditional normal trade relations treatment from the US. SEC. 3. REMOVAL OF PROVISIONS RESTRICTING TRADE AND OTHER RELATIONS WITH CUBA. The text chunk discusses the repeal of certain authorities related to trade with Cuba, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Trading With the Enemy Act. It also mentions the removal of export prohibitions under the Export Administration Act of 1979. The Act under the Export Administration Act of 1979 related to trade with Cuba will cease to be effective. The President can impose new export controls and exercise authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act in response to a national emergency. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, including related amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing certain paragraphs and sections from various acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing references to Cuba and certain subsections related to exports. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing references to Cuba and certain subsections related to exports. Additionally, sections 909, 910, and 911 are repealed, along with the prohibition on transactions or payments with respect to certain United States intellectual property and the sugar quota prohibition under the Food Security Act of 1985. SEC. 4 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrading facilities. SEC. 5 pertains to travel. SEC. 5 allows travel to and from Cuba for US citizens without regulation. Transactions related to travel, such as banking activities, are also permitted. The President is required to negotiate with Cuba to settle US nationals' property claims and engage in dialogue for human rights protection, based on previous bilateral meetings and dialogues. The US and Cuba initiated discussions in 2016. Definitions for "national of the United States" and "property" are based on the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. SEC. 7. EXTENSION OF NONDISCRIMINATORY TRADE TREATMENT. The Congress believes that the US should support democratic change and economic reform in Cuba by normalizing trade relations. Upon the enactment of this Act, the US will no longer need to use article XXI of the GATT 1994 with respect to Cuba. The President still has the authority to invoke article XXI of the GATT 1994 in the future. The Uruguay Round Agreements Act extends nondiscriminatory treatment to Cuban products by amending the Harmonized Tariff Schedule and repealing section 401 of the Tariff Classification Act of 1962. This Act terminates the application of title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Cuba, ensuring normal trade relations treatment for Cuban products. The Trade Act of 1974 will no longer apply to Cuban products, ensuring normal trade relations treatment. The effective date for these changes will be 15 days after the Act's enactment. The President must report to Congress on US-Cuba trade relations within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8 prohibits limiting annual remittances to Cuba by individuals under U.S. jurisdiction, with exceptions for money laundering offenses. All existing regulations restricting remittance amounts must be rescinded. SEC. 9 states that the Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment.
